Description: Bioscrip agreed to pay $15 million to settle allegations involving an alleged kickback scheme with Novartis.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York
Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: BioScript agreed to pay $1 million in settlement of allegations it improperly billed Medicaid when it automatically refilled prescriptions that were not specifically requested by the patient, violating Medicaid regulations.

BioScrip agreed to pay $5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it overbilled Medicaid and other government health care programs for prescription medications by treating the government programs as the primary insurance carrier even when the patients had other insurance coverage.

BioScrip agreed to pay $3.31 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it paid unlawful kickbacks to doctors to induce them to prescribe Exjade and thus caused false claims to be submitted to state Medicaid programs. This was part of a larger $15 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-bioscrip-inc

Option Care, University of Wisconsin Hospital Pharmacies, and Hemophilia Outreach Center agreed to reimburse Medicaid the charges made for dispensing blood clotting factor concentrates, in settlement of allegations they did not comply with Medicaid dispensing requirements for the product.
